Research highlights:
Mesoporous silica based ligand immobilized nano-conjugate materials was fabricated. The Co(II) ions was captured with specific color formation at optimum condition. The proposed materials exhibited high selectivity and sorption capacity to Co(II) ions.
Graphical Abstract
A B S T R A C T
Simultaneous detection and removal of heavy metals with high sensitivity and adsorption capacity of a suitable material is an ultimate goal in industry for the purification of contaminated water samples. This study was investigated the use of functional ligand immobilized mesoporous silica based nano-conjugate materials for efficient detection and removal of cobalt (Co(II)) ions from wastewaters with optical color optimization. The mesoporous silica, newly prepared organic ligand and the nano-conjugate materials were characterized systematically. The effect of pH on the sensitivity and selectivity of the formed complexes was studied after adding the Co(II) ions in specific condition. Under optimum conditions, the nano-conjugate materials was formed visible color after capturing of the Co(II) ions. The data of calibration graphs were linear in the low concentration level of Co(II) ions with the detection limit of 0.33 µg/L. The performance of the solid-phase adsorption was enriched the Co(II) ions efficiently into the materials surface. The kinetic performance was high and the isotherm study was conducted using the Langmuir adsorption model. The results exhibited very high adsorption capacity of 170.17 mg/g and this capacity was compared with different forms of materials. In addition, the materials was adsorbed the Co(II) ions with higher 96% from the synthetic multi-mixture metal ions containing samples and this is confirmed the materials high selectivity for efficient detection and adsorption of Co(II) ions. Desorption experiments were carried out with 0.30 M HCl proved that without significant loss in its original performance that could be reused in several cycles. Therefore, the proposed materials here is an interesting and promising attempt for the trace Co(II) ions capturing in water samples and will have much more applied field.
Keywords: Nano-conjugate materials; Cobalt ions; Detection and adsorption; High adsorption; Reuses.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A trace amount of cobalt (Co(II)) is essential to the human body as it is the major
constituent in vitamin B12 [1-3]. However, the Co(II) is a non-biodegradable heavy metal and it is commonly found in the metallic state with coexisting of sulfide minerals along with copper, nickel and iron in sulfide mineral and in some cases as Co(II) arsenide. Also the Co(II) is found in industrial wastewater due to the diverse application in industrial sectors such as magnetic and stainless steels, electronics, porcelain, radioisotope therapy, galvanizing, battery recharging, metal plating, paints and pigment industries, mining operations, nuclear power plant grinding wheels and tanneries [4-6]. Then the Co(II) inherent toxicity has been increasing and causing the serious problem because the higher concentration of Co(II) is very harmful [7]. The acute Co(II) poisoning in humans can cause several diseases such as vomiting, asthma, lung irritations, diarrhea, pneumonia, weight loss, nausea, heart failure, bronchitis and adversely affected of thyroid and liver [3,8,9]. It is also reported that excess amount of Co(II) inside the body can cause gene mutation and cancer [10,11]. Then it is clarified that the damage from Co(II) existed waste samples created the certain threat to human health [12]. Therefore, developing smart devices for the monitoring and removal of Co(II) ions in the wastewater samples are important in the field of environmental and food analysis due to matter of water quality, environmental eco-system and human health.
Many methods have been developed for metal ions detection including, AAS, cold
vapour atomic fluorescence spectrophotometry, ICP-AES/OES, ICP-MS, liquid chromatography, UV–vis spectrometry, electrochemical method, capillary electrophoresis, flow injection chemiluminescence, enzyme analysis method, X-ray fluorescence and optical nano-sensors [13-17]. ICP-AES/OES and ICP-MS are able to determine the multi-elements at one time according to their mass charge ratios based on multi-element detectors. However, these are limited in the operating environment and made them high expensive techniques
[18,19]. Then the alternative method came forth based on the optical vision and less expensive idea. Nowadays, optical sensors are attractive technique for ultrasensitive determination of diverse metal ions, thanks to its high sensitivity and selectivity with significant color optimization in charge-transfer complexation mechanism. In addition, the sensors provide the scope of portability from the stand point of low cost and fast analysis procedures [3,20]. In our earlier report, we have prepared mesoporous silica based conjugate materials for detecting and separating of Co(II) ions at optimum conditions [21]. In this study, we have prepared the conjugate materials by ligand impregnation onto the mesoporous silica composite for the improvement of the detection sensitivity, adsorption capacity for potential application in the onsite analysis.
There are numbers of metal ions removal methods have been reported from the
wastewater samples including chemical precipitation, liquid–liquid extraction, cloud point extraction, solid phase extraction, reverse osmosis, filtration methods, electrocoagulation technique, biological technology and adsorption with ion exchange by chelating resins and complexation mechanisms [22-26]. From the point of view of low cost, several bioadsorbents such as bamboo, peat, tyre, bagasse and bone char [7, 27-30] have been reported for remediation of water pollution. This is noted that these bio-adsorbents are low yield and very high processing temperatures required for their activation and in many case they are unable to reuse in many cycles. On the other hand, adsorption with suitable adsorbents is commonly used technique for treating the industrial wastewater based on the operational flexibility, high adsorption rate with extreme efficiency and reversibility. Then it is necessary to develop a new type adsorbent with high selectivity, large adsorption capacity, and good reusability compared with the traditional adsorbents.
Recently, functional ligand anchoring materials have gained the scientific attention
due to the chemical functionality with high stability, high adsorption rate and extreme
selectivity at optimum conditions [31-33]. In this connection, we have prepared mesoporous silica composite materials and then incorporated with the organic functional ligand and then proceed the metal ions separation based on the pH dependent. The usage of widely studied ligand in the preparation of nano-conjugate materials gave an opportunity to save a lot of experimental efforts when considering the fact of sensitivity, selectivity, time, stability and large-scale use [34-36]. In addition, the ligand molecule was molecular receptor, which transformed their chemical information into analytical signals upon binding to the metal ions at specific pH region. The present work describes our investigations of the monitoring and removal of Co(II) ions in colorimetric methods. Then the designing of robust technology that can remove the contaminants from wastewater with rapid environmental analysis and lowcost is highly demanded. Moreover, the process is simple and rapid, reversible, economical and eco-friendly technology with high sorption capacity.
In this work, new type of organic ligand of N,N-disalicylidene-4,5-dimethyl-
phenylenedene (DDPD) was synthesized and successfully immobilized onto the mesoporous silica to use the nano-conjugated materials for simultaneous optical detection and removal method for trace level Co(II) ions. Several influencing factors for detection and removal including, pH values, color optimization, detection limit, contact time, ion selectivity and reuses were studied and optimized in a systematical way. The enrichment performance of Co(II) ions was evaluated by the comparison of the proposed method and reported articles. The Co(II) ions detection and removal were demonstrated as cost-effective, rapid and easyto-use without using sophisticated instruments.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
All materials and chemicals were of analytical grade and used as it was.
Tetramethylorthosilicate (TMOS), F108 (EO141PO44EO141), Al(NO3)3·9H2O, salicylaldehyde and 2,4-diaminoanisole were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich Company Ltd. USA. The standard Co(II) ions solutions and other metal salts were purchased from Wako Pure Chemicals, Osaka, Japan. The buffer solutions of 3–morpholinopropane sulfonic acid (MOPS) and sodium acetate were procured from Dojindo Chemicals, Japan, and KCl, HCl and NaOH from Wako Pure Chemicals, Osaka, Japan. Ultra-pure water was used throughout in this work.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis and characterization of DDPD ligand
sections.text:
The Schiff base ligand of N,N-disalicylidene-4,5-dimethyl-phenylenedene (DDPD)
was prepared by condensation between the diamine and the hydroxyaldehyde in ethanol and was purified by recrystallization from a dichloromethane/hexane mixed solvent through the partial evaporation of the more volatile dichloromethane as reported [37a]. The DDPD was fabricated by dissolving 25 mmol (3.404 g) of 4,5-dimethyl-1,2-phenylenediamine in 100 ml of ethanol and stirred for 3 h. After that (8.306 gm) of 3-formyl-4-hydroxybenzoic acid was mixed in 150 mL of ethanol. The 4,5-dimethyl-1,2-phenylenediamine solution was added to the salicylaldehyde solution using an overhead stirred for complete mixing. The crude product was re-crystallized from dichloromethane/hexane (1:2) mixed solvent.

sections.heading: 2.3. Analyses
sections.text:
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained by using a JEOL (JEM-2010)
and operated at the accelerating voltage of the electron beam at 200 kV. The TEM samples were prepared by dispersing the powder particles in ethanol solution using an ultrasonic bath and then dropped on copper grids. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were carried out by BELSORP MIN-II analyzer at 77 K. The specific surface area (SBET) was calculated using
multi-point adsorption data from the linear segment of the N2 adsorption isotherms using Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) theory. The absorbance spectrum was measured by UV– Vis–NIR spectrophotometer (Shimadzu-3700). The metals concentrations were measured by ICP–AES. The ICP–AES instrument was calibrated using five standard solutions containing 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0 mg/L (for each element), and the correlation coefficient of the calibration curve was higher than 0.9999. In addition, sample solutions having complicated matrices were not used and no significant interference of matrices was observed.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of mesoporous silica and nano-conjugate materials
sections.text:
The mesoporous silica was synthesized by using triblock copolymers as direct
templating liquid-crystal phase using microemulsion system where F108 surfactant was used. In typical conditions, the composition mass ratio of F108:TMOS:HCl/H2O was 1.3:2:1 respectively. The homogeneous sol-gel synthesis was achieved by mixing of F108/TMOS in a 500 mL beaker and then shaking at 60°C until homogeneous. The exothermic hydrolysis and condensation of TMOS occurred rapidly by addition of acidified aqueous 2.5 g of HCl (pH = 1.3) solution to this homogeneous solution. The flask that contained the synthesis composition was instantly connected to the rotary evaporator at 45 °C to remove the methanol. After that the materials were dried at 45 °C for 24 h to complete the drying process. Organic moieties were removed by calcination at 500 °C under normal atmosphere for 6 h.
The nano-conjugate material was fabricated by direct immobilization method. The
DDPD (60 mg) was added to the N, N–dimethylformamide (DMF) solution and then 1.0 g mesoporous silica was added to the solution. The immobilization procedure was performed under vacuum at 55°C until DDPD saturation was achieved. The DMF was removed by a vacuum connected to a rotary evaporator at 80°C and the resulting nano-conjugate material
was washed with warm water to check the stability of DDPD ligand onto mesoporous silica. Then the material was dried at 45°C for 6 h and ground to fine powder for Co(II) detection and removal operations. In the DDPD immobilization onto mesoporous silica, the total washing amount of DDPD solution was counted the determination of DDPD immobilized amount. The DDPD immobilization amount (0.11 mmol/g) was determined by the following equation:
Q = (C0 – C) V/m (1)
where Q is the adsorbed amount (mmol/g), V is the solution volume (L), m is the mass of substrates (g), C0 and C are the initial concentration and supernatant concentration of the DDPD, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.5. Detection and removal of Co(II) ions
sections.text:
In the detection operation, the nano-conjugate material was immersed in a mixture of
specific Co(II) ion at appropriate pH of 2.0, 3.50 (0.2 M of KCl with HCl), 5.20 (0.2 M CH3COOHCH3COONa with HCl), 7.01 (3-morpholinopropane sulfonic acid (MOPS) with NaOH), 8.0, 9.50 (0.2 M 2–(cyclohexylamino) ethane sulfonic acid (CHES) with NaOH), 11.0 (0.2 M N–cyclohexyl–3–aminopropane sulfonic acid (CAPS) with NaOH) with shaking in a temperature-controlled water bath with a mechanical shaker at 25°C for 30 min at a constant agitation speed of 110 rpm to achieve optimum color. The blank solution was also prepared, following the same procedure for comparison of color formation before and after addition of Co(II) ions. After optimum color formation, the solid material was separated by filtration and used for color assessment. The nano-conjugate material was ground into fine powder to achieve homogeneity in the absorbance spectra for linear color enhancement. The limit of detection (LD) was determined from the linear part of the calibration plot according to the following equation [37b,38]:
LD = KSb/m (2)
where, the value of K is 3, Sb is the standard deviation for the blank and m the slope of the calibration graph in the linear range, respectively.
The removal experiments were performed at room temperature (25°C) and the Co(II)
ion adsorption was calculated from the following equations:
Mass balance qe = (C0 – Cf) V/M (mg/g) (3)
(C0 – Cf) and metal removal efficiency R = x 100 (%) (4) C0
where V is the volume of the aqueous solution (L), and M is the weight of the nano-conjugate material (g), C0 and Cf are the initial and final concentrations of Co(II) in solutions, respectively.
To evaluate the eluting agent, Co(II) ion was adsorbed by the conjugate material and
then washed with water several times and transferred into a 50 mL beaker. The washing solution was also checked by the ICP-AES. However, the 0.30 M HCl was used as a suitable eluent in this study. After the regeneration operation, the nano-conjugate material was reused for several cycles to check the reusability of the conjugate material.
All experiments in this study were duplicated at least to assure the consistency and
reproducibility of the results.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of mesoporous silica and conjugate material
sections.text:
The N2 adsorption–desorption is introduced to analyze the porous structure
nanomaterials [39,40]. According to Fig. 1, the mesoporous silica and ligand embedded nano-conjugate materials exhibited the type of IV isotherm with H2 shaped which was indicated by mesoporous structure. Even after ligand anchoring, the nano-conjugate material
as illustrated in Fig. 1 (b) was also the mesoporous material as hysteresis loop indicated as the same shape of the mesoporous silica. The total BET surface areas of the mesoporous silica and the nano-conjugate material are listed in Fig. 1 (inset). The nano-conjugate materials surface area and pore volume were decreased as expected after ligand immobilization. Thus the nano-conjugate material can potentially be used to capture the Co(II) ions at optimum conditions from effluents due to the creation of highly ordered mesoporous structure.
Fig. 2 (A and B) shows the TEM images of the mesoporous silica. These images are
uniform arrangement pores and continuous arrays along all directions which indicate the ligand immobilization possibility as the interaction between the ligand and mesoporous silica into the rigid condensed pore surfaces with retention of the ordered structures make the materials suitable for high transport of the metals at optimum condition [36]. In addition, the images are perpendicularly to the direction of the pore channels and showed well-organized parallel channels and clarified a hexagonally ordered array. After DDPD ligand immobilization onto the mesoporous silica, the recorded TEM images also shown a well arrangement pores and continuous arrays along all directions as judged from Fig. 2 (C and D). All these changes may be a consequence and the nano-conjugate material exhibited appreciated porous structure for Co(II) ions capturing from water solutions.

sections.heading: 3.2. Co(II) ions detection
sections.text:
The pH of the sample solution has a very important factor for the colorimetric
detection method with the complex formation between the functional materials and the analytes [41]. In this parameter measurement, the influence of pH was determined by varying solution pH within the range from 2.0 to 11.0 where the pH was adjusted by buffer solution as indicated in the experimental section. The absorbance intensity was determined with
formation color as a function of pH and the data are displayed in Fig. 3. Fig. 3 also shows that the absorption intensities are affected by the variation of solution pH in the range 2.0– 11.0. This means that sensitivity and selectivity are strongly depended on the pH value. The data clarified that the maximum absorption intensity was received at pH 8.0. Then the pH 7.0 was chosen as an optimum condition to determine the others parameters in the detection method.
In order to understand the high sensitivity with the optimum color formation, it is
important to select the variable concentration that guarantees complex formation with increasing the absorbance intensity in terms of color enhancement. The effect of Co(II) ions concentration on the absorption of the complex for color optimization was investigated and the data are shown in Fig. 4 (A). The results indicated that the color enhancement was increased with increasing the concentration. Moreover, the absorbance intensity was increased where the shaking time was fixed at 15 min. The color formation was visualized by the naked-eye as judged of Fig. 4 (A) in the inset.
The calibration curve was obtained based on the color optimization as a function of
absorbance intensity as depicted in Fig. 4 (B). The linearity was obtained when the concentration range from 0.003 to 0.10 mg/L as the liner line shown in Fig. 4 (B) (inset). The linear regression equation was expressed as Y = 0.04946 + 0.53672 X with a correlation coefficient of 0.9978. The calculated limit of detection (LOD) was 0.33 µg/L based on the Eq. (2), which indicates that the prepared materials easily detect of Co(II) ions at the ultratrace concentration level optically without using sophisticated experimental procedures.
Most of the alkali and alkaline earth metals are usually present in the real sample and
these ions do not have much affection to form complexation with the ligand functionalized nanomaterials in the case detection system [42,43]. On the other hand, transition metal ions may form the complexation with the ligand at the optimum condition and can cause the
interference of the Co(II) ions detection. Then the effects of diverse ions on the simultaneous detection was evaluated while each of the metals ions of Na+, K+, Ag+, Ba2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Pb2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cd2+ and Cu2+ ions concentration was 10 mg/L and the Co(II) ions was 1.0 mg/L. The tolerance limit was taken as the amount of the added foreign ions causing a relative error of less than ±5% in the detection procedure. Fig. 5 shows the signal intensity of the each metals ions and anions. The minimal increase in the absorbance intensity with the addition Cu2+ and Zn2+ ions was observed and this ions considered as disturbance species as judged from slight changes in both the color and signal intensity when this metal ions concentrations in solution exceeded 10-fold. Except for these two metal ions, none of these metals have no spectral lines near the Co(II) ions with the specific detection of Co(II) ions. This is probably due to the stronger attraction of the DDPD and Co(II) ion to form more stable complexes in Co(II) ions capturing system.

sections.heading: 3.3. Removal of Co(II) ions
sections.text:
It is well known that solution pH is one of the key important parameters affecting the
metal ion adsorption due to the points of the protonation of the functional groups on the adsorbent surface and also on the solution chemistry properties of the metal ions according to their hydrolysis, complexation, and redox reaction tendency. Therefore, the first factor studied in the present work is the effect of pH on Co(II) ions adsorption by the nanoconjugate material. The Co(II) ions remains as prevailing species up to pH 8.0 and then the major hydroxyl species are Co(OH)+, Co(OH)2, Co(OH)3 - based on the speciation diagram [44,45]. As shown in Fig. 6 (A), the Co(II) ion adsorption by the nano-conjugate materials is pH dependent and the adsorption efficiency increases with increasing the solution pH from 3.5 to 8.0. On the other hand, However, the Co(II) ion adsorption was low below the pH value of 3.5. This is the fact that when the hydronium concentration is increased by reducing the pH, the competition between the hydronium ion and the Co(II) ions to capture the
adsorption sites is increased and subsequently hydronium ion defeats the Co(II) ions in reaching the site. Then the Co(II) ions adsorption was low. Similarly, the presence of high amount hydronium ions exerted the repulsive forces to the Co(II) ions hindering them to approach the nano-conjugate materials surface. Therefore, pH 8.0 is suitable for efficient Co(II) ions adsorption by the proposed nano-conjugate materials.
In the evaluation of transient behavior as a function of contact time to reach
equilibrium was determined by the propose nano-conjugate materials. The investigation of this parameter can save money and energy in the case of industrial-scale adsorption processes when the proposed materials are potential. The Co(II) adsorption by the nano-conjugate materials in terms of contact time is shown in Fig. 6 (B). With increasing the contact time, reflects the increasing trend of the Co(II) adsorption process. The higher adsorption rate was observed in the initial stage where readily available reaction sites for the Co(II) ions adsorption and the equilibrium is attained at 50 min. However, an equilibration time of 3 h was selected to determine the maximum Co(II) ions adsorption by the nano-conjugate materials in this present study when the initial concentration was high. On the other hand, the fibrous materials and granular resin are exhibited high kinetic performances even in the anions adsorption [46-48].
The maximum Co(II) ions adsorption capacity was determined based on the variation
of initial concentration where other parameters were fixed. Then the each point of adsorption capacity was plotted according to the Langmuir adsorption isotherms model. Here the Freundlich was not considered because the adsorption surface is homogenous as judged from the materials characterization. In addition, the Freundlich equation assumes a heterogeneous surface including of various energies and considers that there is an exponential increase in metal ions concentrations on the material with an increase in the metal ions concentration in the liquid phase. On the other hand, the Langmuir adsorption model is based on the
assumption that all the adsorption sites are homogeneous and energetically equivalent, which clarified the monolayer coverage as the surface is in homogenous. Moreover, there is no interaction of the surface molecules and these molecules can be bound to the surface independent of the occupation of the neighboring adsorption sites. Then the Langmuir isotherm model is the monolayer coverage of the adsorption surfaces and predicted that metal ions adsorption homogeneously. Then the experimental adsorption data are shown in Fig. 7. The linear form of the Langmuir adsorption isotherm model is:
Ce/qe = 1/(KLqm) + (1/qm)Ce (linear form) (5)
where qe and Ce are the equilibrium concentrations when an adsorbate get adsorbed onto the nano-conjugate materials. Also qm (mg/g) represents the maximum adsorption capacity, KL (L/mg) is the Langmuir constant representing the affinity between the solute and nanoconjugate materials. The qm and KL were calculated from the slope and intercept from the plot of Ce/qe versus Ce. The plots of Ce/qe versus Ce for the Co(II) ions adsorption onto the nanoconjugate materials (Fig. 7, inset) represented a straight line. The result clarified that the Co(II) ion adsorption onto materials was fitted well the Langmuir adsorption isotherm model as the evident of correlation coefficient factors (R2 = 0.9933). The maximum Co(II) ions adsorption capacity was 170.17 mg/g based on the calculation method where the adsorption coefficient KL was calculated to be 1.214 L/mg. The results also complied that the surface of the nano-conjugate materials is homogenous and the adsorption exhibited in monolayer coverage. The maximum Co(II) ions adsorption capacity by the present nano-conjugate materials is compared with other forms divers materials in Table 1 and adsorption capacity exhibited as promising as reported with the materials in the literature [3,7,30,44,49,50].
It is an important parameter to judge the adsorption system for co-ions besides the
metal ion of interest. Moreover, the real wastewater has contained several ions and these are interacted with many ions. Therefore, an efficient material should be able to remove a target chemical species even in the presence of competitive cations and anions. The common cations present in water are Na+, K+, Ag+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Ba2+, Pb2+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Cd2+ and Cu2+ and these ions also can affect the Co(II) ion adsorption by the nano-conjugate materials. Fig. 8 (A) shows the preferential affinity for nano-conjugate materials to the each metal ion with adsorption efficiency. The data clarified that the proposed materials was capable to adsorbed the Co(II) ions from the multi-mixture solution even each of metal ions concentration was 5 times higher than the Co(II) ions concentration. Therefore, it is effective for the Co(II) ions adsorption in presence/absence of different metal ions which make the nano-conjugate materials as a suitable candidate for the treatment of Co(II) containing wastewater.

sections.heading: 3.4. Desorption & regeneration studies
sections.text:
The reusability of the proposed materials is important in the practical and potential
applications of wastewater effluents treatment [3,45,51]. Moreover, the reversibility and stability of between Co(II) ions and the functional group of nano-conjugate materials are also a very critical factor. The desorption operation of the Co(II) ion adsorbed materials was checked with different concentration of HCl solution. The Co(II) ions adsorption-desorption was subjected to eight cycles, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 (B). As shown in Fig. 8 (B), fifth recycle, the adsorption amount decreased only by ca. 6% and this may be the experimental error as the materials amount might be reduced due to the several steps including washing. The data also clarified that the Co(II) ions adsorption capacity by the nano-conjugate materials was still exceeded ca. 89% even after the eighth cycle. This results
also proved that the Co(II) ions complexation bonding is a stable for the efficient Co(II) ion adsorption process with high efficiency.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The present study demonstrated the effectiveness of the ligand based nano-conjugate
material for the detection and instantaneous removal of Co(II) ions from the aqueous solution. The ability of the ligand functionalized materials was systematically evaluated for effective Co(II) ions capturing using colorimetric approaches. The presented method offers important advantages in terms of fabrication and the analysis processes. The data showed that the Co(II) ions determined optically with the significant color formation at optimum conditions with high sensitivity and selectivity. The preferable pH for the effective adsorption was optimized at 7.0 and equilibrium studies confirmed the Langmuir isotherm model which indicates the adsorption process was monolayer with stable complexation mechanism. In addition, the determined maximum adsorption capacity for Co(II) ions by the proposed materials was 170.17 mg/g. In competitive adsorption studies clarified that nano-conjugate materials was selective toward Co(II) ions even in the presence of diverse metal ions. This means that Co(II) ions can selectively be removed from an aqueous solution, which provides a new method for recycling Co(II) ion in order to realize Co(II) ion resource utilization. The reuses studies also evaluated and the data illustrated that the Co(II) ions adsorption capacity was high without obvious decrease in the adsorption capacity even after several cycles, which it is very potential for Co(II) ions capturing from industrial wastewater. The suggested method provides some key advantages, such as simplicity of experimental steps, cost-effective and reliable for low concentration Co(II) ions detection and removal without using sophisticated instruments. Therefore, the new nano-conjugate materials have the potential to provide easy-
to-use, interference-free and effective solution for Co(II) ions capturing from wastewater samples.

metadata.abstractText: Simultaneous detection and removal of heavy metals with high sensitivity and adsorption capacity of a suitable material is an ultimate goal in industry for the purification of contaminated water samples. This study was investigated the use of functional ligand immobilized mesoporous silica based nano-conjugate materials for efficient detection and removal of cobalt (Co(II)) ions from wastewaters with optical color optimization. The mesoporous silica, newly prepared organic ligand and the nano-conjugate materials were characterized systematically. The effect of pH on the sensitivity and selectivity of the formed complexes was studied after adding the Co(II) ions in specific condition. Under optimum conditions, the nano-conjugate materials was formed visible color after capturing of the Co(II) ions. The data of calibration graphs were linear in the low concentration level of Co(II) ions with the detection limit of 0.33 μg/L. The performance of the solid-phase adsorption was enriched the Co(II) ions efficiently into the materials surface. The kinetic performance was high and the isotherm study was conducted using the Langmuir adsorption model. The results exhibited very high adsorption capacity of 170.17 mg/g and this capacity was compared with different forms of materials. In addition, the materials was adsorbed the Co(II) ions with higher 96% from the synthetic multi-mixture metal ions containing samples and this is confirmed the materials high selectivity for efficient detection and adsorption of Co(II) ions. Desorption experiments were carried out with 0.30 M HCl proved that without significant loss in its original performance that could be reused in several cycles. Therefore, the proposed materials here is an interesting and promising attempt for the trace Co(II) ions capturing in water samples and will have much more applied field.
